messages: [{'account_id': 17799, 'date': '2019-05-20 21:49:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17799, 'date': '2019-05-21 00:57:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-05-21 15:51:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28008, 'date': '2019-05-21 15:57:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 17799, 'date': '2019-05-21 18:20:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:\n\nrecheck git.openstack.org was temporarily broken at the time repo_build wanted to clone everything'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-20 21:49:08.000000000', 'message': 'Zuul: Simplify the integrated test playbooks

When using the integrated repo for testing, only the openstack-ansible
repository can be used to kick off the tests - so if any other repo
uses it, it will always be the same path.

The existing implementation modeled from the openstack-ansible-tests
repo which implemented a job and set of playbooks which would allow
the tests to execute from any one of the other repositories - which
is not the case here.

There is therefore no reason to have this path be dynamic in any way,
so we hard code it to where we know zuul has it.

We also remove other unnecessary fact setting and ensure that bash is
used when running gate-check-commit.

Change-Id: I17780e48cac97b1f3888b8cb264c284d8ece44a1
(cherry picked from commit ab0b3abb75bdc6c4a1d86a59c08b87246cd2b025)
(cherry picked from commit bdd79bd0a678b5621b1840c012fa122b429d0738)

There is therefore no reason to have this path be dynamic in any way,

We also remove other unnecessary fact setting and ensure that bash is
used when running gate-check-commit.

Change-Id: I17780e48cac97b1f3888b8cb264c284d8ece44a1
(cherry picked from commit ab0b3abb75bdc6c4a1d86a59c08b87246cd2b025)
(cherry picked from commit bdd79bd0a678b5621b1840c012fa122b429d0738)
'}]
commit_message:
Zuul: Simplify the integrated test playbooks

When using the integrated repo for testing, only the openstack-ansible
repository can be used to kick off the tests - so if any other repo
uses it, it will always be the same path.

The existing implementation modeled from the openstack-ansible-tests
repo which implemented a job and set of playbooks which would allow
the tests to execute from any one of the other repositories - which
is not the case here.

There is therefore no reason to have this path be dynamic in any way,
so we hard code it to where we know zuul has it.

We also remove other unnecessary fact setting and ensure that bash is
used when running gate-check-commit.

Change-Id: I17780e48cac97b1f3888b8cb264c284d8ece44a1
(cherry picked from commit ab0b3abb75bdc6c4a1d86a59c08b87246cd2b025)
(cherry picked from commit bdd79bd0a678b5621b1840c012fa122b429d0738)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-21 10:02:54.000000000', 'message': 'Add cinder credentials to nova conf

Added user/project CONF with admin role at cinder group,
and when determine context is_admin and without token, do
authenticaion with user/project info to call cinder api.

When set reclaim_instance_interval > 0, and then delete an
instance which booted from volume with `delete_on_termination`
set as true. After reclaim_instance_interval time pass,
all volumes boot instance with state: attached and in-use,
even when attached instances was deleted.

This happens because as admin context from
`nova.compute.manager._reclaim_queued_deletes` did not have
any token info, then call cinder api would be failed.

The corresponding nova changes merged in change

commit_message:
Add cinder credentials to nova conf

Added user/project CONF with admin role at cinder group,
and when determine context is_admin and without token, do
authenticaion with user/project info to call cinder api.

When set reclaim_instance_interval > 0, and then delete an
instance which booted from volume with `delete_on_termination`
set as true. After reclaim_instance_interval time pass,
all volumes boot instance with state: attached and in-use,
even when attached instances was deleted.

This happens because as admin context from
`nova.compute.manager._reclaim_queued_deletes` did not have
any token info, then call cinder api would be failed.

The corresponding nova changes merged in change
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/522112/

Also rephrased CinderPassword parameter description in
cinder service templates to make it generic.

Conflicts:
      deployment/nova/nova-compute-container-puppet.yaml

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/660329/
Related-Bug: #1734025
Change-Id: If0f9e442e5ed3b2d94bc51e65c145519c51cbc86
(cherry picked from commit 8f8b750e4f5767665f6e2fe2ae2b3dca17be2b61)

commit_message:
use publish for SUBNETPOOL_ADDRESS_SCOPE callback events

Today all the code for SUBNETPOOL_ADDRESS_SCOPE callback events uses
the payload style kwargs, however 1 use still calls notify() rather
than publish() which should be used for the payload style callbacks.
This patch fixes the issue.

NeutronLibImpact

Change-Id: Icc598169cc07db7270d452834439953b3bf273c2

commit_message:
Avoid fullstack QoS tests to handle other test ports

In order to isolate the concurrent execution of fullstack QoS tests,
the function QosAgentExtension._process_reset_port() is mocked to
avoid any port reset created by other test.

Change-Id: Ib78098387e90b6c315d3e969004f5786ace8696e
Closes-Bug: #1824138

[{'created': '2019-04-18 14:39:07.000000000', 'message': "Don't count ports with inactive bindings as serviceable dvr ports

In case of live migration, binding of port on src host is first switched
to be INACTIVE and then L3 agent should remove qrouter namespace from
compute node if that was last port connected to this router on host.
Because of bug which didn't check if port which is on host has ACTIVE
or INACTIVE binding, router namespace wasn't cleaned properly.

"}]
commit_message:
Don't count ports with inactive bindings as serviceable dvr ports

In case of live migration, binding of port on src host is first switched
to be INACTIVE and then L3 agent should remove qrouter namespace from
compute node if that was last port connected to this router on host.
Because of bug which didn't check if port which is on host has ACTIVE
or INACTIVE binding, router namespace wasn't cleaned properly.
Now it is cleaned as only ports with ACTIVE binding are count
as serviceable ports on compute node.

Change-Id: I01173ad64a19fc05a888c601b81ec097d579a7cf
Closes-Bug: #1825205

commit_message:
use trunk constants from neutron-lib

The trunk constants now live in neutron-lib. This patch consumes them
by removing neutron.services.trunk.constants and using them from
neutron-lib instead.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/650372/

NeutronLibImpact

Change-Id: I4445c44c7e321d0fc35976d4d855c148bb9a3b18

[{'created': '2019-04-12 07:37:27.000000000', 'message': "Reorder classless static route (RFC3442) records

Ratio: if there are Subnet1 with Host1 and Subnet2 with Host2 and
Host2 serves Network2 behind it, in order to reach Network2 it is
required to add Network2 to Subnet1's host_routes with Host2 as a
nexthop. In this case Neutron will offer in Subnet1 the following set
of RFC3442 routes:

Network2 -> Host2
Subnet2_cidr -> 0.0.0.0

which will lead to fail installing Network2 route on the Host1 since
at the moment of Network2's appearance there is no information about
Subnet2 route.

The proposed patch orders routes in such a way that 'connected' routes
(0.0.0.0) will be placed first and, thus, all subsequent routes will
be installed succesfully.

Change-Id: Ice70eb2090e1e99c72ae51601fefd7ec5cd8867a

commit_message:
Reorder classless static route (RFC3442) records

Rationale: if there are Subnet1 with Host1 and Subnet2 with Host2
and Host2 serves Network2 behind it, in order to reach Network2 it is
required to add Network2 to Subnet1's host_routes with Host2 as a
nexthop. In this case Neutron will offer in Subnet1 the following set
of RFC3442 routes:

Network2 -> Host2
Subnet2_cidr -> 0.0.0.0

which will lead to fail installing Network2 route on the Host1 since
at the moment of Network2's appearance there is no information about
Subnet2 route.

The proposed patch orders routes in such a way that 'connected' routes
(0.0.0.0) will be placed first and, thus, all subsequent routes will
be installed succesfully.

Change-Id: Ice70eb2090e1e99c72ae51601fefd7ec5cd8867a

commit_message:
Add log file for neutron-keepalived-state-change

neutron-keepalived-state-change may not start but have no method
to find out why. This patch adds the log file for it.

Change-Id: I688a6e6d0ac42c00d87571484f726e0eae091675
Related-Bug: #1822155

commit_message:
Check in "_update_segmentation_id" that the mech_driver has an agent

In [1] it is assumed that all mechanism drivers have an agent, but the
mech driver API [2] doesn't enforce it. VIF types will be retrieved
only from those mechanism drivers with an associated agent.

[1]https://review.openstack.org/#/c/633165/20/neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py@814
[2]https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/stable/stein/neutron_lib/plugins/ml2/api.py#L37

Change-Id: I5c334f31259871ed5251d5d4a2ba8cae36bd2355
Closes-Bug: #1824346

commit_message:
Include 'octavia' driver on ML2/OVN deployments

By default, both the 'amphora' and 'octavia' provider drivers are
enabled in Octavia API. A previous change in puppet-tripleo included the
'ovn' driver when on Neutron ML2/OVN deployments but in doing so omitted
the 'octavia' driver. This patch ensures the 'octavia' driver remains
enabled as is needed for Octavia Tempest tests.

Change-Id: I5b29a51d7edace30e6357a2af95d1af4596ddfd3

commit_message:
Remove broken docs jobs from monasca-agent

zuul shows only failures for this non-voting job and has no success in
its database. Looking at the repo, it is not setup correctly, so let's
remove a job that is broken. Monasca team can run this inside their repo
once they are ready.

Change-Id: I589c3975b49e4453a2576b6123da4ec7d97638a7

commit_message:
Switch some repos to PTI docs jobs

Switch repos diskimage-builder, pynotedb, subunit2ql, faafo,
interop-workloads
to use the PTI docs jobs instead of the obsolete build-sphinx ones.

The repos have been checked, building with tox -e docs works.

Change-Id: Ide05dece01b418c9d7ec1aee04ddc4706ac75f7b

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-21 16:36:37.000000000', 'message': 'Drop jobs for devstack-plugins-sheepdog

This is step 2 in retiring this project. The Sheepdog project is no
longer actively maintained, and support will be removed for it from
OpenStack.

http://lists.wpkg.org/pipermail/sheepdog/2019-March/068451.html

commit_message:
Drop jobs for devstack-plugins-sheepdog

This is step 2 in retiring this project. The Sheepdog project is no
longer actively maintained, and support will be removed for it from
OpenStack.

http://lists.wpkg.org/pipermail/sheepdog/2019-March/068451.html

Change-Id: I74da0e810e9dd98f23ef4e511f579f468ea5707e
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add more channel number for detecting BMC IP address

IPMI SPEC[1] assignment channel number 1-11 for vendors
implementation(We an search "Channel Numbers" in section 6.3).
We met an baremetal product, like H3C, use number 8 as LAN channel.

Current code limit channel number to 1~7,
I think this can increase to 1~11.

[1] https://www.intel.com/content/dam/www/public/us/en/documents/product-briefs/ipmi-second-gen-interface-spec-v2-rev1-1.pdf

Change-Id: I63a6ff91d702b990ef09da13e6e2e269e7274cce
Task: 30654
Story: 2005528
(cherry picked from commit 66d3c8e453a58c01740581079045e9b4368c4bde)

commit_message:
Do not use metadata checksums with ext4

Remove metadata_csum option when creating filesystems
since cirros doesn't support it.
This option was added in Debian stretch and Ubuntu bionic
as default and it breaks compatibility with filesystems
created with older versions.

(cherry picked from commit 4e086f9f0fa2cfdd215994c76025bdb7954e3610)

Change-Id: I6772e455f5d1ee7587c2dc43203b02e5e54cb714

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-15 15:30:46.000000000', 'message': "Fix retry of instance_update_and_get_original

_instance_update modifies its 'values' argument. Consequently if it is
retried due to an update conflict, the second invocation has the wrong
arguments.

A specific issue this causes is that if we called it with
expected_task_state a concurrent modification to task_state will cause
us to fail and retry. However, expected_task_state will have been popped
from values on the first invocation and will not be present for the
second. Consequently the second invocation will fail to perform the
task_state check and therefore succeed, resulting in a race.

We rewrite the old race unit test which wasn't testing the correct
thing for 2 reasons:

1. Due to the bug fixed in this patch, although we were calling
   update_on_match() twice, the second call didn't check the task state.
2. side_effect=iterable returns function items without executing them,
   but we weren't hitting this due to the bug fixed in this patch.

Closes-Bug: #1821373
Change-Id: I01c63e685113bf30e687ccb14a4d18e344b306f6
(cherry picked from commit aae5c7aa3819ad9161fd2effed3872d540099230)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix retry of instance_update_and_get_original

_instance_update modifies its 'values' argument. Consequently if it is
retried due to an update conflict, the second invocation has the wrong
arguments.

A specific issue this causes is that if we called it with
expected_task_state a concurrent modification to task_state will cause
us to fail and retry. However, expected_task_state will have been popped
from values on the first invocation and will not be present for the
second. Consequently the second invocation will fail to perform the
task_state check and therefore succeed, resulting in a race.

We rewrite the old race unit test which wasn't testing the correct
thing for 2 reasons:

1. Due to the bug fixed in this patch, although we were calling
   update_on_match() twice, the second call didn't check the task state.
2. side_effect=iterable returns function items without executing them,
   but we weren't hitting this due to the bug fixed in this patch.

Closes-Bug: #1821373
Change-Id: I01c63e685113bf30e687ccb14a4d18e344b306f6
(cherry picked from commit aae5c7aa3819ad9161fd2effed3872d540099230)

commit_message:
Handle failed neutron-plugin-ml2.yaml lookup

This handles the puppet/services/neutron-plugin-ml2.yaml template
GET failure by simply hard coding the 'ovn' default which matches
the latest t-h-t templates default anyway for this template.

Change-Id: Ic7c1817671467f4ec2ef823f52e165c2c1f230ca

commit_message:
Remove deprecated admin ssl options

The ssl_cert_admin and ssl_key_admin are being removed from
puppet-keystone so we need to stop using them in puppet-tripleo.

Change-Id: Ibe97accb22820d02abfa076515967336da4c8800
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658382/

subject: Add public resource loading and message parsing
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 10239, 'name': 'Dmitry Tantsur', 'email': 'dtantsur@protonmail.com', 'username': 'dtantsur'}, {'_account_id': 11655, 'name': 'Julia Kreger', 'email': 'juliaashleykreger@gmail.com', 'username': 'jkreger', 'status': 'On the moon! With a jetpack!'}, {'_account_id': 16635, 'name': 'deray', 'email': 'debayan.ray@gmail.com', 'username': 'deray'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23851, 'name': 'Riccardo Pittau', 'email': 'elfosardo@gmail.com', 'username': 'elfosardo'}, {'_account_id': 27909, 'name': 'Aija Jauntēva', 'email': 'aija.jaunteva@dell.com', 'username': 'ajya'}, {'_account_id': 29209, 'name': 'Dhanuka Warusadura', 'email': 'csx@tuta.io', 'username': 'dnuka'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2018-08-10 11:02:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2018-08-10 11:55:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2018-08-14 17:59:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2018-08-14 18:59:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2018-09-24 19:16:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2018-09-24 19:17:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2018-10-24 19:51:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2018-11-01 12:37:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 29209, 'date': '2018-11-26 10:43:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Thank you for the patch! Would a release note make sense?'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2018-12-03 19:49:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> Thank you for the patch! Would a release note make sense?

thank you for reminding about release notes. As this is one patch in chain of many patches to support new feature, I will add release note to the final patch [1]
Also at this stage all these additions are non-public and not meant to be exposed to end-user.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/591635/'}, {'account_id': 16635, 'date': '2018-12-05 09:32:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

Actually it reminds me of a similar concept available in Java I/O package APIs. Those I/O APIs use the modular 'chaining' concept so that you can hook together
connection streams and chain streams in a wide range of combinations to get just about anything you could want. The chains don't have to stop at two levels;
you can hook multiple chain streams to one another to get just the right amount of processing you need. For instance, the readers of java API are designed and
used as following:

    BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader(new File("C:\\testing.txt")));

where the BufferedReader is a chain reader and the FileReader can be considered as the real connection reader.

Now, mapping such kind of use cases for our scenario we can have the class hierarchy as:

    @six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta)
	class AbstractJsonReader(object):

        @abc.abstractmethod
		def get_json(self):
		    pass


    # Connection Reader
    class HttpJsonResponseReader(AbstractJsonReader):
	    """Gets the data from HTTP response given by path"""

        def __init__(self, connector, path):
            self._conn = connector
            self._path = path

        def get_json(self):
            return self._conn.get(path=self._path).json()

        def get_content(self):
            return self._conn.get(path=self._path).content


    # Connection Reader
    class LocalJsonFileReader(AbstractJsonReader):
	    """Gets the json data from local filesystem given by file path"""

        def __init__(self, file_path):
            self._file_path = file_path

        def get_json(self):
            with open(self._file_path) as f:
			    return json.load(f)

        def get_content(self):
            with open(self._file_path) as f:
			    return f.read()

    # Chain Reader - can extract from any zip content
    class JsonArchiveReader(AbstractJsonReader):
	    """Gets the data from JSON file in archive"""

        def __init__(self, json_content_reader, archive_file):
            self._json_content_reader = json_content_reader
			self._archive_file = archive_file

        def get_json(self):
            data = self._json_content_reader.get_content()
			# extract from zipped content and return plain json content

Now reflecting on the Sushy ResourceBase class::

    class ResourceBase(object):

        def __init__(self, connector, path='', redfish_version=None):
		    ...  # no reader argument passed in here

        def _fetch(self):
		    return HttpJsonResponseReader(self._conn, self._path).get_json()

        def refresh(self, ...):
            ...
			self._json = self._fetch()
			...

For resource classes where in the data needs to be fetched from local file system, we can override the ``_fetch()`` method as:

    def _fetch(self):
	    # self._conn is not relevant here, so even while the object can get
		# instantiated with connector as None.
	    return LocalJsonFileReader(file_path=self._path).get_json()

and the other use cases we have in here for MessageRegistry::

    if location.uri:

        return message_registry.MessageRegistry(
            self._conn, path=location.uri,
            redfish_version=self.redfish_version)

    elif location.archive_uri:
        
        # ``_fetch()`` method patcher
        def archive_fetch(selfie):
            json_content_reader = HttpJsonResponseReader(self._conn, location.archive_uri)
            return JsonArchiveReader(json_content_reader, location.archive_file).get_json()

        return type('MessageRegistryFromArchive',
                    (message_registry.MessageRegistry,),
                    {'_fetch': archive_fetch})(
                        self._conn, path=location.archive_uri,
                        redfish_version=self.redfish_version)

    elif location.publication_uri:

        # ``_fetch()`` method patcher
        def public_uri_fetch(selfie):
            return HttpJsonResponseReader(public_connector, location.publication_uri).get_json()

        return type('MessageRegistryFromPublicUri',
                    (message_registry.MessageRegistry,),
                    {'_fetch': public_uri_fetch})(
                        self._conn, path=location.archive_uri,
                        redfish_version=self.redfish_version)

Although I haven't tested this code myself but I genuinely hope that this should work (possibly with some improvements with optimization).
I also feel that the idea I wanted to bring forth is to reuse the different connection and chain reader functionalities across different
use cases within our context by decorating the functionalities. Just for example, possibly we may face a situation where we need to get the
plain json content from an archived-zipped content which is on local filesystem. In order to support such cases we shouldn't create multiple
classes, like 'HttpArchiveJsonReader' and 'LocalFileArchiveJsonReader' and so on and so forth. Moreover, mandating to pass a None value connector to a ``LocalJsonFileReader`` instance should completely be avoided in the first place.

I am all ears about what you think.'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2018-12-12 19:19:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

Debayan, thanks for idea, I will look into it to get it working.

Until then see 1 response inline.'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2018-12-30 21:40:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi Debayan,

I took a look at your other suggestions - I like the chaining idea, but not sure if it is worth it now as it would save only 1 line to fetch the resource from the Internet. Could be added in the future, when, e.g., Redfish spec adds cases where archives could be retrieved from the Internet, local Redfish service or local filesystem. At the moment Archives come only from the Internet. Then there could be resource fetcher from these 3 sources and 1 unarchiver chained to the fetcher as necessary.

About the other suggestion with _fetch implementation: I think it makes code unnecessarily more complicated. Instead of passing reader instance, here we pass _fetch method. Also, as _fetch is intended to be "private", should caller (e.g., from MessageRegistry) be exposed to it at all? At the moment this is necessary only for Message Registry, but what if in future new resources arrive that could come from different types of sources, then would need to repeat the same code again and again (or create re-usable patcher, e.g., something like readers as they are now). Also patchers are longer code and less straightforward than creating a new instance of desired reader.

To me the only "ugly" thing now is that for local filesytem reader connector needs to be passed as None, but maybe there is cleaner way how to solve this. In C-like languages I would create a constructor overload without this parm, but this is not an option in Python. In Python could move this to optional parm with default value None, but this would require refactoring of the `ResourceBase` constructor to move `connector` after mandatory/positioned args.

Let me know what you think.'}, {'account_id': 16635, 'date': '2019-01-04 11:08:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Thank you Aija for your detailed response. I am not sure if I have got all of what you have pointed out to me but please see my response specific comments to better understand what I have got (or failed to get).

> About the other suggestion with _fetch implementation: I think it makes code unnecessarily more complicated. Instead of passing reader instance, here we pass _fetch method. 

What I could understand from the code was that in case of MessageRegistry the data source could be of 3 different types, local Redfish service plain json content, local Redfish service with archived json content and from public uri json content. So, my intention was to create 2 more instantaneous dynamic classes (MessageRegistryFromArchive & MessageRegistryFromPublicUri) and their corresponding objects along with the already available general MessageRegistry class object. Those 2 classes only differ in their ``_fetch()`` method and nothing else from the general MessageRegistry class. And I did it in the way I did as I could make use of lexical scoping of python to get hold of the data (location.archive_file / location.publication_uri) I needed inside the ``_fetch()`` method.

> Also, as _fetch is intended to be "private", should caller (e.g., from MessageRegistry) be exposed to it at all? 

Caller is not supposed to call this method as ``refresh()`` is the only available API to her. ``_fetch()`` is rather meant towards the implementor of any subclass of BaseResource to amend the fetching method as intended.

> At the moment this is necessary only for Message Registry, but what if in future new resources arrive that could come from different types of sources, then would need to repeat the same code again and again (or create re-usable patcher, e.g., something like readers as they are now). 

I don't know if I have got query/concern fully. My answer would be; not necessarily. Say for example if we have any class which is also supposed to get its data from a local Redfish service with archived json content, then it always makes sense to create a class, like BaseResourceFromArchive, and have the _fetch() method implemented accordingly. And then MessageRegistryFromArchive and that new resource class can be derived from that and can have their respective attributes defined over there.'}, {'account_id': 16635, 'date': '2019-01-04 11:10:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> I took a look at your other suggestions - I like the chaining idea, but not sure if it is worth it now as it would save only 1 line to fetch the resource from the Internet. Could be added in the future, when, e.g., Redfish spec adds cases where archives could be retrieved from the Internet, local Redfish service or local filesystem. At the moment Archives come only from the Internet. Then there could be resource fetcher from these 3 sources and 1 unarchiver chained to the fetcher as necessary.

Btw I am completely fine if you are suggesting that we can take such kind of implementation in future and not now!'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2019-01-06 17:46:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Debayan, thanks for response, 

> What I could understand from the code was that in case of MessageRegistry the data source could be of 3 different types, local Redfish service plain json content, local Redfish service with archived json content and from public uri json content

Correct, what I meant with my previous comment that essentially this is not very different from passing a different reader as needed instead of dynamic classes. I see dynamic classes as more complex solution that is not necessary here because the options here are limited and can be pre-defined and it requires that registry implementer understands the internals of base resource which I wouldn't ask of them (more on this below).

> Caller is not supposed to call this method as ``refresh()`` is the only available API to her. ``_fetch()`` is rather meant towards the implementer of any subclass of BaseResource to amend the fetching method as intended.

here I distinguish between different sushy developers, not sushy users(callers). At one level there is sushy developer who develops and maintains base resources. Then there is sushy developer who just adds new resources and as long there are no fundamentally new scenarios not supported by base resources, this sushy developer does not need to know the internals of base resource class. That's why I don't ask this resource developer to be aware of private `_fetch` and override the method. Generally private implementation of base resource shouldn't be exposed so that this allows us to change it later just in case without breaking sub-resources. This is also known as encapsulation.
Moreover, it wouldn't be intuitive to find out that this needs _fetch override, while if readers were used then it would be "discoverable" through constructor parameters.

> then it always makes sense to create a class, like BaseResourceFromArchive, and have the _fetch() method implemented accordingly. And then MessageRegistryFromArchive and that new resource class can be derived from that and can have their respective attributes defined over there.

Correct, but why not use readers the same way as they are now - JsonFileReader, JsonPublicFileReader etc. given the drawbacks I see for overriding `_fetch` as described above?

In summary, I see that your proposed solution has 2 new additions 1) chaining readers 2) _fetch override.
The 1st would solve the many combinations that can arrive in future - archive file, plain json file in combination with filesytem file, path inside Redfish service, absolute path on the Internet.
For the 2nd I see that it breaks encapsulation principle and the concept is not fundamentally different from the readers concept - meaning, both allow to define how to fetch the resource, but readers don't break encapsulation and is more discoverable.

I hope this shed some light on my point of view.'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2019-02-12 19:09:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2019-02-12 19:16:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2019-02-25 19:24:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-02-25 21:03:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-02-28 10:28:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2019-02-28 20:29:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2019-02-28 20:30:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(2 comments)

rebased and see inline'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2019-05-17 09:17:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-05-21 18:35:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add public resource loading and message parsing

Adds:
* support for loading resources from the Internet
using full URL,
* load all provided message registries based on their source,
* combine provided message registries with standard message
registries,
* parse a message using the message registries.

Change-Id: I5a85344c094e890554c400fc87a960dc4cccb8b6
Story: 2001791
Task: 23062

should be marked as backport'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-05-20 17:28:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-05-21 08:21:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-26 16:48:15.000000000', 'message': 'Downgrade Logstash for Monasca

Logstash was added to Kolla as part of the effort to deploy Monasca.

Monasca uses Kafka messaging version 0.9 which is not supported by
Logstash 5.x with the default Kafka input/output plugins. An attempt
to downgrade the plugins to the 4.x series which should be compatible
with messaging version 0.9 and Logstash 5.x failed. Therefore, until
Monasca is upgraded (work is ongoing) this patch downgrades
Logstash to 2.4.1.

Although it would have been simpler to perform the downgrade by
blacklisting the Logstash 5.x package which is provided as part of the
official ELK repo and installing the official repo for Logstash 2.4.1,
Ubuntu 18.04 no longer accepts SHA1 hashes (for good reason) and will
not install Logstash 2.4.1 from this repo (fails with GPG error).
This approach does however work for Centos, but for consistency it
was not used.

This change therefore modifies the Logstash dockerfile, and directly
downloads and installs the Logstash 2.4.1 package. It should be
reverted as soon as Monasca is upgraded.

Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-containers
Change-Id: I58fba9ceded4b3a198136df084c7d37365ab47a8
'}]
commit_message:
Downgrade Logstash for Monasca

Logstash was added to Kolla as part of the effort to deploy Monasca.

Monasca uses Kafka messaging version 0.9 which is not supported by
Logstash 5.x with the default Kafka input/output plugins. An attempt
to downgrade the plugins to the 4.x series which should be compatible
with messaging version 0.9 and Logstash 5.x failed. Therefore, until
Monasca is upgraded (work is ongoing) this patch downgrades
Logstash to 2.4.1.

Although it would have been simpler to perform the downgrade by
blacklisting the Logstash 5.x package which is provided as part of the
official ELK repo and installing the official repo for Logstash 2.4.1,
Ubuntu 18.04 no longer accepts SHA1 hashes (for good reason) and will
not install Logstash 2.4.1 from this repo (fails with GPG error).
This approach does however work for Centos, but for consistency it
was not used.

This change therefore modifies the Logstash dockerfile, and directly
downloads and installs the Logstash 2.4.1 package. It should be
reverted as soon as Monasca is upgraded.

Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-containers
Change-Id: I58fba9ceded4b3a198136df084c7d37365ab47a8

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-21 09:55:13.000000000', 'message': 'Add cinder credentials in nova conf

Added user/project CONF with admin role at cinder group,
and when determine context is_admin and without token, do
authenticaion with user/project info to call cinder api.

When set reclaim_instance_interval > 0, and then delete an
instance which booted from volume with `delete_on_termination`
set as true. After reclaim_instance_interval time pass,
all volumes boot instance with state: attached and in-use,
even when attached instances was deleted.

This happens because as admin context from
`nova.compute.manager._reclaim_queued_deletes` did not have

The corresponding nova changes merged in change
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/522112/

commit_message:
Add cinder credentials in nova conf

Added user/project CONF with admin role at cinder group,
and when determine context is_admin and without token, do
authenticaion with user/project info to call cinder api.

When set reclaim_instance_interval > 0, and then delete an
instance which booted from volume with `delete_on_termination`
set as true. After reclaim_instance_interval time pass,
all volumes boot instance with state: attached and in-use,
even when attached instances was deleted.

This happens because as admin context from
`nova.compute.manager._reclaim_queued_deletes` did not have
any token info, then call cinder api would be failed.

The corresponding nova changes merged in change
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/522112/

Related-Bug: #1734025
Change-Id: Ib58c2ca04dfe6d1e1ff849f600a9a24724205078
(cherry picked from commit 848ac0b5e101850e7c3ad5140ac87e5476603f1b)

commit_message:
Do not try to return mock as JSON in unit tests

A few of our unit tests make API handlers return Mock objects. This
used to work with older WSME, but the current master has dropped
support for simplejson, which has apparently made validation stricter.
An example of resulting failures can be seen in RDO CI:
https://trunk.rdoproject.org/centos7/71/83/71833957b3e9c4bdc7b1992e768e1b01a9339e97_156a4cd0/mock.log

This change fixes it, also adding autospec=True to affected tests.

Change-Id: Ide4bc301d53ad81b53e5df8a9358cb65fdd8056c
(cherry picked from commit f8e1fbf30879e883f2e77386b7f275fd5afbff25)

commit_message:
Compatible with old Swift service enable

Some of gate job, like ironic-inspector-tempest-dsvm-python3 doesn't
support data stores in Swift[1]. If use swift as tempest default
config, it will breaks that stable branch gate job.

This patch add backward compatibility for swift, and lets default data_store
is None.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/ironic-inspector/blob/stable/rocky/devstack/plugin.sh#L271-L273

Change-Id: Id349ab8c1cf90632032233c7a754e60544efd057

[{'created': '2019-05-16 19:33:24.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure dvr ha router gateway port binding host

There are some extreme conditions which will result the unbound
router gateway port. Then all the centralized floating IPs will
not be reachable since the gateway port was set to 4095 tag.

This patch adds the HA status to the router related port
processing code path. If it is HA router, the gateway port
will go to the right HA router processing code branch.

Closes-Bug: #1827754
Change-Id: Ida1c9f3a38171ea82adc2f11cb17945d6e2434be
(cherry picked from commit 3d99147e732ab4cdad0b8243e5fabb6a8954aa72)
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure dvr ha router gateway port binding host

There are some extreme conditions which will result the unbound
router gateway port. Then all the centralized floating IPs will
not be reachable since the gateway port was set to 4095 tag.

This patch adds the HA status to the router related port
processing code path. If it is HA router, the gateway port
will go to the right HA router processing code branch.

Closes-Bug: #1827754
Change-Id: Ida1c9f3a38171ea82adc2f11cb17945d6e2434be
(cherry picked from commit 3d99147e732ab4cdad0b8243e5fabb6a8954aa72)

commit_message:
Extract provider tree functional tests into new file.

test_servers.py was already far too big, so move all tests relating to
the provider tree out into test_servers_provider_tree.py, as discussed
on IRC:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2019-05-20.log.html#t2019-05-20T15:44:22

Change-Id: Ibbd57a78b23efe368d92aa6ba0f9ee2d31728e5a

Argh, sorry - this time I forgot to push a patch set before rebasing in order to make the inter-patch-set diffs easier to follow :-/

Changes over patch set 9 are as follows:

- Now that XXX landed, the emulator binary path is available from calling the getCapabilities() API and parsing the result, so use that: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/633855/9..10/nova/virt/libvirt/host.py
@740

- Call getDomainCapabilities once per architecture, and memoize each resulting parsed object in a dict of dicts: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/633855/9..10/nova/virt/libvirt/host.py@680

- Move _machine_type_mappings() and a small chunk of _get_machine_type() to libvirt_utils so that they can be reused from libvirt.host.Host: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/633855/9..10/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py@4230

- Rebase and resolve minor conflicts.

Again this has been tested on real SEV hardware (using I2b41f1cce0af8b9d36b74a4663aa4ff227e17cc6 on top) and it still works nicely :-)'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-03-07 23:58:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-30 01:13:59.000000000', 'message': "Add detection of SEV support from QEMU/AMD-SP/libvirt on AMD hosts

In order to support booting of SEV-enabled guests on AMD hosts which
are SEV-capable, we first need to be able to automatically detect
which hosts are capable of supporting SEV.  This requires checking for
support in two places:

- The sev parameter of the kvm_amd kernel module (which indicates that
  the kernel provides support)

- The host's libvirt domain capabilities, as indicated in the response
  from a virConnectGetDomainCapabilities() API call; if the <features>
  element includes <sev supported='yes'/> then this indicates that
  both QEMU and the AMD Secure Processor (AMD-SP) support SEV
  functionality, whereas <sev supported='no'/> indicates that QEMU
  doesn't support it, and the absence of any <sev> element indicates
  that libvirt doesn't even know about the feature:

    https://libvirt.org/git/?p=libvirt.git;a=commit;h=6688393c6b222b5d7cba238f21d55134611ede9c

This commit addresses the second of these two checks.  Subsequent
commits will address the first, add logic which combines both checks
and provides a new standard trait which indicates that both checks
have passed, and of course ultimately make use of that new trait.

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: I4c35b6a27db05349213429422ffe62adb09bd921

In order to support booting of SEV-enabled guests on AMD hosts which
are SEV-capable, we first need to be able to automatically detect
which hosts are capable of supporting SEV.  This requires checking for
support in two places:

- The sev parameter of the kvm_amd kernel module (which indicates that

- The host's libvirt domain capabilities, as indicated in the response
  from a virConnectGetDomainCapabilities() API call; if the <features>
  element includes <sev supported='yes'/> then this indicates that

This commit addresses the second of these two checks.  Subsequent
commits will address the first, add logic which combines both checks
and provides a new standard trait which indicates that both checks
have passed, and of course ultimately make use of that new trait.

Since this change adds the mechanism for calling
virConnectGetDomainCapabilities(), it also lays some groundwork for
the handle-default-machine-type-as-q35 blueprint.

  that libvirt doesn't even know about the feature:

    https://libvirt.org/git/?p=libvirt.git;a=commit;h=6688393c6b222b5d7cba238f21d55134611ede9c

This commit addresses the second of these two checks.  Subsequent
commits will address the first, add logic which combines both checks,
provide a new standard trait which indicates that both checks
have passed, and of course ultimately make use of that new trait.

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: I4c35b6a27db05349213429422ffe62adb09bd921
"}]
commit_message:
Add detection of SEV support from QEMU/AMD-SP/libvirt on AMD hosts

In order to support booting of SEV-enabled guests on AMD hosts which
are SEV-capable, we first need to be able to automatically detect
which hosts are capable of supporting SEV.  This requires checking for
support in two places:

- The sev parameter of the kvm_amd kernel module (which indicates that
  the kernel provides support)

- The host's libvirt domain capabilities, as indicated in the response
  from a virConnectGetDomainCapabilities() API call; if the <features>
  element includes <sev supported='yes'/> then this indicates that
  both QEMU and the AMD Secure Processor (AMD-SP) support SEV
  functionality, whereas <sev supported='no'/> indicates that QEMU
  doesn't support it, and the absence of any <sev> element indicates
  that libvirt doesn't even know about the feature:

    https://libvirt.org/git/?p=libvirt.git;a=commit;h=6688393c6b222b5d7cba238f21d55134611ede9c

This commit addresses the second of these two checks.  Subsequent
commits will address the first, add logic which combines both checks,
provide a new standard trait which indicates that both checks
have passed, and of course ultimately make use of that new trait.

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: I4c35b6a27db05349213429422ffe62adb09bd921

commit_message:
Async notify neutron-server for HA states

RPC notifier method can sometimes be time-consuming,
this will cause other parallel processing resources
fail to send notifications in time. This patch changes
the notify to asynchronous.

Closes-Bug: #1824911
Change-Id: I3f555a0c78fbc02d8214f12b62c37d140bc71da1
(cherry picked from commit 0f471a47c073eb0cf2ed68c30482e1ae71ff6927)

commit_message:

This role only support openSUSE Leap 15, not 42.3, not tumbleweed.
Saying all is confusing and a bad practice. This fixes it, while
ensuring the job is properly defined to test that assertion.

commit_message:
Clear out keystone package config on ubuntu

See Bug 1737697.  The ubuntu packaging provides a default keystone.conf
which we want to remove because we manage the keystone vhost
configuration via puppet. This change moves the logic we had in
puppet-openstack-integration into puppet-keystone proper.  Once the code
is removed from p-o-i, we can switch these to actual file resources
rather than using ensure_resource

Change-Id: Iea8f531a8eff4c053cff01a7f75ce43024c97c7b

commit_message:
Keep HA ports info for HA router during entire lifecycle

Once HA port is set, it must remain this value no matter
what the server return. Because there is race condition
between l3-agent side sync router info for processing
and server side router deleting.

This patch adds a helper function for every ha_port set
action. If the ha_port is not None, it will always stay
with original value.

Conflicts:
	neutron/tests/unit/agent/l3/test_ha_router.py

Closes-Bug: #1826726
Change-Id: I96a088d25048be02a9c5b12c1d087df075b36fc4
(cherry picked from commit 45957f12c897f6dcdf3676649a28dac866450afd)
(cherry picked from commit 13cb3cd34c26b6e6668732d664b640a69cec4dec)

[{'created': '2019-05-19 07:39:02.000000000', 'message': 'Remove obsolete docs job from neutron-tempest-plugin-jobs

Currently, neutron repo builds docs twice: with the PTI job
openstack-tox-docs which is part of publish-openstack-docs-pti and with
the obsolete job build-openstack-sphinx-docs which is part of
neutron-tempest-plugin-jobs.

The template neutron-tempest-plugin-jobs is only used for this repo and
for neutron.

Change-Id: I7e5cb3a3fc1b6da0f4b335b631fbaa071cf74631
'}]
commit_message:
Remove obsolete docs job from neutron-tempest-plugin-jobs

Currently, neutron repo builds docs twice: with the PTI job
openstack-tox-docs which is part of publish-openstack-docs-pti and with
the obsolete job build-openstack-sphinx-docs which is part of
neutron-tempest-plugin-jobs.

The template neutron-tempest-plugin-jobs is only used for this repo and
for neutron.

Fix:
* Remove the obsolete doc building job so that only the new PTI job is used.

* Add the template build-openstack-docs-pti so that the new PTI jobs run
  on this repo.

Change-Id: I7e5cb3a3fc1b6da0f4b335b631fbaa071cf74631

[{'created': '2019-04-16 05:54:05.000000000', 'message': "[heat] create pike-em tag against final releases

This is a procedural review to transition pike into extended maintenance by
creating the pike-em tag

It's possible that the release isn't needed (for example if there are no code
changes sine the previous release, sadly that's non-trivial to detect en masse.

If you are the PTL or release liaison for this team please +1 this review
if it is ready or -1 and take over the review to correct mistakes.

Change-Id: Ibba5629850762d515db87c828342a9b67e5ea08c
"}]
commit_message:
[heat] create pike-em tag against final releases

This is a procedural review to transition pike into extended maintenance by
creating the pike-em tag

It's possible that the release isn't needed (for example if there are no code
changes sine the previous release, sadly that's non-trivial to detect en masse.

If you are the PTL or release liaison for this team please +1 this review
if it is ready or -1 and take over the review to correct mistakes.

Change-Id: Ibba5629850762d515db87c828342a9b67e5ea08c

commit_message:
Debian: Add support for placement-api over uwsgi

Under Debian, placement-api runs over uwsgi, and has its own
systemd .service file. Let's support this.

Change-Id: I56954855f0ad3686f620044aa951ececf8e289df

commit_message:
Bump etcd role to v3 capable SHA

etcd v3 is required by the upgraded version of Calico that is
compatiable with openstack versions Queens and later.

The systemd_service role is added with a null trackbranch and a SHA
pinned at the current HEAD of the role's stable/rocky branch. That
is necessary because the etcd role's tags which install etcd3 utilize
the systemd_service role to build a unit file for starting etcd.

Depends-On: I746b9dbb090dd484a36e826f06beda1eba3f55f4
Change-Id: I04bb2773d5e55e73f29b2c24013005ea814d3992
(cherry picked from commit 00a451c874aa63047ad0da4f34f62cf318d2ac78)

commit_message:
New documentation for in-flight validations

This new validation type allows to ensure, between deploy/upgrade
steps, services are in the right state.

Change-Id: I1f9d717ebd0cd854efa5a63280016e2969bba713
Implements: blueprint inflight-validations

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-21 07:20:11.000000000', 'message': 'Switch to openstackdocstheme

With the recent Sphinx release the previously used oslosphinx
theme is no longer functional. It is fine to switch over
to the more openstack standard openstackdocstheme which is
maintained and working with the new Sphinx.

Move doc-specific requirements for the docs process into
a separate doc/requirements.py and remove it from test-reqiurements.

Change-Id: I075a02bb9efbfc9c39277bc8ce7330e20bf91605
'}]
commit_message:
Switch to openstackdocstheme

With the recent Sphinx release the previously used oslosphinx
theme is no longer functional. It is fine to switch over
to the more openstack standard openstackdocstheme which is
maintained and working with the new Sphinx.

Move doc-specific requirements for the docs process into
a separate doc/requirements.py and remove it from test-reqiurements.

Change-Id: I075a02bb9efbfc9c39277bc8ce7330e20bf91605

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-26 10:01:07.000000000', 'message': 'Add monasca user to Monasca thresh container

The monasca-thresh container is special in that inherits from
the Storm container so that it has access to the Storm client.
We could make monasca-base inherit from Storm, but it would
bloat the other Monasca images which may not run on the same
nodes as the Storm topology.

Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-containers
Change-Id: Idd1703b72e45bb9d124e06a28738b18da0bc6918
'}]
commit_message:
Add monasca user to Monasca thresh container

The monasca-thresh container is special in that inherits from
the Storm container so that it has access to the Storm client.
We could make monasca-base inherit from Storm, but it would
bloat the other Monasca images which may not run on the same
nodes as the Storm topology.

Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-containers
Change-Id: Idd1703b72e45bb9d124e06a28738b18da0bc6918

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.  Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: Id90e02a9001c75260bc429b544ea1a312d647405

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ia37608cb7aa95388fdd49ed18128bb1f2fa6125b

commit_message:
Adds Ansible variables support

Extensive use of ansible variables to render configmaps. Makes the
use of hiera optional.

Removed redundant openshift specific deployment config tasks

Change-Id: Iee9e7fcabf92cfdc5b6b4a8d0b8bcf57d8777be4

commit_message:
DRY out Zuul job configuration

Adds a new abstract parent job for the following kayobe deploy jobs:

kayobe-overcloud-centos
kayobe-overcloud-upgrade-centos
kayobe-seed-centos
kayobe-seed-upgrade-centos

This parent includes commonly used variables, and pre-run and post-run
playbooks for preparing and executing diagnostics, plus other
initialisation.

Change-Id: I9ab89fbc49bb32d86af56d50ec3914740e65d0f8

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/642030/'}]

commit_message:
Re-propose the spec to allow specifying a list of CPU models

[The spec was originally proposed for Stein, by Jack Ding
<jack.ding@windriver.com>, here:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/620959/. Kashyap Chamarthy try to
re-propose the spec and had been abandoned, here:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/642030/. This spec is based on Kashyap
Chamarthy's work.]

Previously-approved: Stein

blueprint: cpu-model-selection
Change-Id: If285d06e768a34c8f7d93117a73272b5f391747f

commit_message:
Use six.viewkeys instead of dict.keys to avoid py2 to py3 problems

This change fixes an 'RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during
iteration' error that is raised because of different behaviour between
python2 and python3. We use the six library to ensure that the behavior
is compatible across versions.

Change-Id: I0723ae10825e1e2d86789627895e3286d8c97602
Resolves-Bug: #1829304
(cherry picked from commit 2c1098b3afb4f5d7cd1d10eaa722652624e6bb74)

commit_message:
Use six.viewkeys instead of dict.keys to avoid py2 to py3 problems

This change fixes an 'RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during
iteration' error that is raised because of different behaviour between
python2 and python3.  We use the six library to ensure that the behavior
is compatible across versions.

Change-Id: I6add03deef77f85fb67992154497773976f9892d
Resolves-Bug: #1829304

Bandit has fixed the problem.

it there as well.

'}]
commit_message:
Cap Bandit below 1.6.0 and update Sphinx requirement

Bandit 1.6.0 accidentally changed how the exclusion list option is
handled and breaks our use of it. Cap to the previous version until
Bandit has fixed the problem.

Sphinx 2.0 no longer works on python 2.7, so we need to start capping
it there as well.

Change-Id: I4ee88377e7123c165434765a73f27cabec8c8177
Reference: https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/pull/489
(cherry picked from commit 3e067530786c7c3f051d75c4579f0254b787c4f5)

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I7ea4cb2da696cfa10551f4cab645db6d47de23d9

commit_message:
Fix rst errors in README

This fixes some rst formatting errors in the README file. The
readme is used as the package long description on pypi, and
they have recently enabled some checks that cause package
upload errors if there are formatting issues with the rst
content.

Change-Id: I3ff7a509c2b875606c985c87b61a63c5e15c1bda
(cherry picked from commit be83eae483cd864d882fc2ef209c8b1d1724a42b)
(cherry picked from commit 770f74861ef9ca218539f5bd387116d95eeb1f17)

subject: Get validations playbooks from playbooks directory
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 11082, 'name': 'Kamil Sambor', 'email': 'ksambor@redhat.com', 'username': 'ksambor'}, {'_account_id': 11491, 'name': 'Gael Chamoulaud', 'email': 'gchamoul@redhat.com', 'username': 'gchamoul'}, {'_account_id': 20775, 'name': 'Carlos Camacho', 'email': 'ccamacho@redhat.com', 'username': 'ccamacho'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 28223, 'name': 'Cedric Jeanneret', 'display_name': 'cjeanner (Tengu)', 'email': 'cjeanner@redhat.com', 'username': 'cjeanner'}, {'_account_id': 28935, 'name': '98k', 'email': '18552437190@163.com', 'username': '98k'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2019-05-08 06:51:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2019-05-08 06:54:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

hmm, are we sure we want to switch Stein as well? Keep in mind some validations are currently being corrected in Master, and we will more than probably overlook some backports on that field...
We aim mostly Train for the Framework. Maybe best to focus on that?'}, {'account_id': 11082, 'date': '2019-05-08 10:28:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2019-05-08 10:59:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> hmm, are we sure we want to switch Stein as well? Keep in mind some
 > validations are currently being corrected in Master, and we will
 > more than probably overlook some backports on that field...
 > We aim mostly Train for the Framework. Maybe best to focus on that?

We already don't use anymore the contents of the validations directory in Stein.

- The contents of the playbooks dir is uploaded into the tripleo-validations swift container by Mistral. Not the validations dir anymore.
- Mistral runs the validations (by group or individually) by calling the playbooks from this swift container. So also the new roles, library and so on from the base directory.
- The code for the 'openstack tripleo validator' subcommand also is already in Stein and is using the two mechanisms listed above.

So, if we want this to be perfectly clean, this patch should also be landed in Stein. Moreover, I don't see the point to maintain two very same validations code in two different space if one is already at 99% not used anymore ?

Am I wrong?"}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2019-05-09 06:32:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

yup, right.'}, {'account_id': 20775, 'date': '2019-05-14 14:28:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28935, 'date': '2019-05-14 14:42:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-05-21 12:46:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Get validations playbooks from playbooks directory

With the new validation framework, all the validations have been
migrated into their own Ansible Roles. The validations are now usable
from tripleo-validations/playbooks directory.

Change-Id: Id836ba2d88f04a90c1738bb71f2aeb07211d2620
Implements: blueprint validation-framework
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 51a9880702686f9ffc0b5781c4824e2c013df76c)

What about freezing, sourcing the file, and non-root? Opinion?'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-09-21 16:05:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> What about freezing, sourcing the file, and non-root? Opinion?

Im wondering if another solution to this would simply be to have a wrapper around the loci heat image? This would remove any requirement from installing packages onto the host, as we have docker already, and also allow us to effectively pin to a known version of the clients very simply.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-09-22 11:58:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Published edit on patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-09-22 11:58:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-09-23 09:39:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> > What about freezing, sourcing the file, and non-root? Opinion?
 > 
 > Im wondering if another solution to this would simply be to have a
 > wrapper around the loci heat image? This would remove any
 > requirement from installing packages onto the host, as we have
 > docker already, and also allow us to effectively pin to a known
 > version of the clients very simply.

Let me rephrase that:

Would you mean you would like an docker image, like the heat one, the have all the clients included, and when a command needs to run, we would run this command in container?

This seems better and more isolated. I would be enclined to not install docker on the host, and make sure this image containing clients is running on kubernetes.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-21 15:03:44.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Nobody cares'}]

[{'created': '2018-09-20 14:54:59.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Do not install pip packages on host

This can conflict with distro provided packaging. Instead, rely
on virtualenv and for convience, alias the usual commands.

Change-Id: Ifa774094e027a7bd8dd8500d428985713305df58
'}, {'created': '2018-09-20 14:58:19.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Do not install pip packages on host

Without this patch, python commands are installed directly on the host,
outside a virtual environment.

This is a problem, because it can conflict with distributions packages,
and will be harder to clean up.

This patch solves the problem by using the distributions's
virtualenv package, and leverage it to build a python virtualenv
which will be self contained. For convenience, an alias is also
created in /etc/profile.d, to allow the user to still use global
'openstack' commands.

Change-Id: Ifa774094e027a7bd8dd8500d428985713305df58

commit_message:
[WIP] Do not install pip packages on host

Without this patch, python commands are installed directly on the host,
outside a virtual environment.

This is a problem, because it can conflict with distributions packages,
and will be harder to clean up.

This patch solves the problem by using the distributions's
virtualenv package, and leverage it to build a python virtualenv
which will be self contained. For convenience, an alias is also
created in /etc/profile.d, to allow the user to still use global
'openstack' commands.

Change-Id: Ifa774094e027a7bd8dd8500d428985713305df58

commit_message:
fix 404 when requesting empty tripleo container image catalog

This patch adds graceful handling for requests against tripleo container
image catalog requests, before the catalog is populated / created.

Change-Id: I0834e095dacb44f0742a15ae67f64c72db7d9c54
Closes-Bug: 1825046

commit_message:
Set arp_notify to match ndisc_notify

A previous change [1] enabled ndisc_notify, which is the IPv6 equivalent
for IPv4's arp_notify.  Enable the latter to keep them consistent with
each other.

Change-Id: I15e8348585a9c0ee824a4c123677992010980b9e
Related-Bug: #1827927
(cherry picked from commit f3df90f2c0afa352d4dcf14463a9364c9080afe6)

commit_message:
Update kubeadm kubernetes version to 1.13.4

This updates the kubernetes version used when deploying via
kubeadm and minikube to v1.13.4

This required updating the apiVersion in the kubeadm configuration
file template, as well as removing the --cadvisor-port flag from
the kubelet args, as this has been removed entirely

Change-Id: I3088b65ece0a5c9c5ef2669247ac293d6a6f66ed

subject: Eliminate SQL injection vulnerability in node_cache
messages: [{'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-05-21 09:06:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-05-21 11:52:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-21 09:06:02.000000000', 'message': 'Eliminate SQL injection vulnerability in node_cache

In node_cache.find_node() we were constructing a raw SQL query using
unescaped data that came in on the wire. This presented an SQL injection
vulnerability. To avoid this, use the query builder from SQLAlchemy to
ensure that any input strings are correctly escaped.

Conflicts:
	ironic_inspector/node_cache.py

Change-Id: I2b0ffa307ec1aa57538733f2e454d2d7e994d656
Story: #2005678
Task: 30992
(cherry picked from commit 9d107900b2e0b599397b84409580d46e0ed16291)
'}]
commit_message:
Eliminate SQL injection vulnerability in node_cache

In node_cache.find_node() we were constructing a raw SQL query using
unescaped data that came in on the wire. This presented an SQL injection
vulnerability. To avoid this, use the query builder from SQLAlchemy to
ensure that any input strings are correctly escaped.

Conflicts:
	ironic_inspector/node_cache.py

Change-Id: I2b0ffa307ec1aa57538733f2e454d2d7e994d656
Story: #2005678
Task: 30992
(cherry picked from commit 9d107900b2e0b599397b84409580d46e0ed16291)

commit_message:
Add version_requirement for kmod in metadata.json

The Forge API requires all metadata.json module
dependencies to have a specified version_requirement
field.

If this is not the case our uploads to the Forge will
fail. [1]

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/56/56ba10b449c6bed9d468d90b12ee8046c77cbb29/release/release-openstack-puppet/fed1fe4/job-output.txt.gz#_2019-05-16_23_10_47_384070

Change-Id: Ib6c8b5b3143260a7e38d5fdd20b91c4440da22fb

commit_message:
Add another nodepool provider ID

And remove unnecessary sourcing of cloud environment.
Everything now is done in ovb-manage role in rdo cloud config repo.
Change-Id: If48cc186f341c59251157d3e3b4c110cacf52495

commit_message:
Update percona-release package

In February 2019, Percona updated their RPM signing keys[1], requiring
the use of an updated percona-release package to install the new
keys.

Also pull in the updated tests-repo-clone script so the correct tests
repo path is used.

openSUSE 42.3 jobs are also removed since 42.3 is EOL soon and the jobs
are broken since they leverage LXC containers.

[1] https://www.percona.com/blog/2019/02/05/new-percona-package-signing-key-requires-update-on-rhel-and-centos/

Depends-On: I67ebe9e813c95a3a8bcf204678ddccbcea7a45cd
Change-Id: I9fb16b7f046530efc124e760bc7870c13b4e8d32

subject: Fix how "has_next_tasks" is calculated for task executions
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-21 10:25:59.000000000', 'message': 'Fix how "has_next_tasks" is calculated for task executions

* There was a weird typo in the list generator expression made in
  https://review.opendev.org/#/c/652575 that led to calculating
  a field value in the wrong way. Fixed. The added test was
  previously failing.

Closes-Bug: #1829841

Change-Id: I6b8ea8dfa623acbb56f649630ddee62e43d484eb
'}]
commit_message:
Fix how "has_next_tasks" is calculated for task executions

* There was a weird typo in the list generator expression made in
  https://review.opendev.org/#/c/652575 that led to calculating
  a field value in the wrong way. Fixed. The added test was
  previously failing.

Closes-Bug: #1829841

Change-Id: I6b8ea8dfa623acbb56f649630ddee62e43d484eb

AFXR queries.

Closes-Bug: #1820089
Signed-off-by: Graham Hayes <gr@ham.ie>
'}]
commit_message:
Allow pdns4 backend to select tsigkey

Allow a new config item in pools.yaml to set the pdns tsigkey to use for
AFXR queries.

Change-Id: Ibb4fb604957286c6edfe85f72321f199eb3167a7
Closes-Bug: #1820089
Signed-off-by: Graham Hayes <gr@ham.ie>

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-03-07 06:02:18.000000000', 'message': '[WIP]Stop admin from deleting tenant tap-services/flows

Currently administrators can delete tenant tap-services/flows.
This is because the Delete class in the plugin accepts only
the id of the resource to be deleted (this is common in most of
the classes in neutron). The current patch proposes to add a check
in the taas_client so that without passing the appropriate tenant-id,
a tap-flow/tap-service cannot be deleted.

Change-Id: Ia8d1ebabc3436ec0359ede31faff41b39d13a5c5

commit_message:
Introduce Policy in Tap-as-a-Service

Currently administrators/ tenants with admin rights can delete
tenant tap-services/flows. This is because the policies are not
properly defined in Tap-as-a-Service.
This patch introduces the policy.json so that the policies can be
properly enforced.

Change-Id: Ia8d1ebabc3436ec0359ede31faff41b39d13a5c5

[{'created': '2017-08-08 07:44:25.000000000', 'message': "DNR WIP :RBAC DB setup and migration for FWP

This patch implements a new database model required for the
firewallpolicy RBAC support. It also migrates the policy attribute
'shared' so that it can be used WRT the new rbac table for firewall
policy.

'shared' property of FirewallPolicy DB model is removed with its status
dependent on the tenant ID of the API caller.
No change in the API therefore users wont be impacted,
but drivers, services etc need to check the new RBAC table instead
of the 'shared' attribute of the firewall-policy DB object

DocImpact
Closes-Bug : #1664814
Change-Id: I50392d0643f98eb02c0e9e5acc2099e713dde99b

commit_message:
WIP :RBAC DB setup and migration for FWP

This patch implements a new database model required for the
firewallpolicy RBAC support. It also migrates the policy attribute
'shared' so that it can be used WRT the new rbac table for firewall
policy. The 'shared' property of FirewallPolicy DB model is removed
with its status dependent on the tenant ID of the API caller.No change
in the API therefore users wont be impacted, but drivers,services need
to check the new RBAC table instead of the 'shared' attribute of
firewall-policy DB object.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1664814
Change-Id: I50392d0643f98eb02c0e9e5acc2099e713dde99b

commit_message:
Add support for DCCP and SCTP in Firewalls

Firewalls support filtering DCCP and SCTP with [1].
This patch provides the support for the same in OSC.

[1]: I312f7f572dab33bd56b0edf395e0e076d3203f5f

Depends-On:  I312f7f572dab33bd56b0edf395e0e076d3203f5f
Change-Id: I0e5c90b06fba82b8c8e04a72fb3919264654feba

"}, {'created': '2019-03-20 18:53:02.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Do not reraise DiskNotFound exceptions during resize

When an instance is in a RESIZE_CONFIRM state, the instance disk on the
source compute host has moved to <instance_path>/<instance_uuid>_resize
folder, which leads to disk not found errors if the update available
resource periodic task on the source compute runs before resize is
actually confirmed.

Icec2769bf42455853cbe686fb30fda73df791b25 almost fixed this issue but it
will only set reraise to False when task_state is not None, that isn't
the case during a resize (there is no actual work happening, we only
wait for the resize confirmation from the user). This patch ensures we
don't reraise DiskNotFound exceptions during resize.

Closes-Bug: 1774249

commit_message:
libvirt: Do not reraise DiskNotFound exceptions during resize

When an instance has VERIFY_RESIZE status, the instance disk on the
source compute host has moved to <instance_path>/<instance_uuid>_resize
folder, which leads to disk not found errors if the update available
resource periodic task on the source compute runs before resize is
actually confirmed.

Icec2769bf42455853cbe686fb30fda73df791b25 almost fixed this issue but it
will only set reraise to False when task_state is not None, that isn't
the case when an instance is resized but resize is not yet confirmed.
This patch adds a condition based on vm_state to ensure we don't
reraise DiskNotFound exceptions while resize is not confirmed.

Closes-Bug: 1774249
Co-Authored-By: Vladyslav Drok <vdrok@mirantis.com>
Change-Id: Id687e11e235fd6c2f99bb647184310dfdce9a08d

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I94abfcc43f0b12d567c6234d05716af4955ea174

[{'created': '2019-04-23 23:09:40.000000000', 'message': "Add infrastructure for invoking libvirt's getDomainCapabilities API

Two use cases have emerged semi-recently which both require the
libvirt driver to be able to invoke libvirt's
virConnectGetDomainCapabilities() API and parse the results:

- Automatic detection of AMD compute hosts which are capable of
  providing SEV (Secure Encrypted Virtualization)

- Gracefully handling different QEMU machine types for x86 hosts

So lay the foundation for these use cases by adding a new
get_domain_capabilities() method to nova.virt.libvirt.host.Host,
along with new subclasses of LibvirtConfigObject for parsing
the XML returned from libvirt, and corresponding tests.

Change-Id: I4aeac9b2397bb2f5e130d1e58829a5e549fcb191
blueprint: gracefully-handle-qemu-machine-types
blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support

commit_message:
Add infrastructure for invoking libvirt's getDomainCapabilities API

Two use cases have emerged semi-recently which both require the
libvirt driver to be able to invoke libvirt's
virConnectGetDomainCapabilities() API:

   https://libvirt.org/html/libvirt-libvirt-domain.html#virConnectGetDomainCapabilities

and parse the results:

- Automatic detection of AMD compute hosts which are capable of
  providing SEV (Secure Encrypted Virtualization)

- Gracefully handling different QEMU machine types for x86 hosts

So lay the foundation for these use cases by adding a new
get_domain_capabilities() method to nova.virt.libvirt.host.Host,
along with new subclasses of LibvirtConfigObject for parsing
the XML returned from libvirt, and corresponding tests.

Change-Id: I4aeac9b2397bb2f5e130d1e58829a5e549fcb191
blueprint: gracefully-handle-qemu-machine-types
blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support

[{'created': '2019-05-02 11:40:52.000000000', 'message': 'Add ODL deprecation warning in CLI

ODL is deprecated since Rocky. Add a warning
before deployment asking the user if he wants
to continue with deployment even after
deprecation.

The logic is to check for neutron-opendaylight.yaml
environment file passed to overcloud deploy command.
If yes, ask for user confirmation before starting
deployment.

Change-Id: I1b16aab11591fac610cd4bf49a0927f1ec947146
Closes-Bug: #1827366

commit_message:
Add ODL deprecation warning in CLI

ODL is deprecated since Rocky. Add a warning
before deployment asking the user if he wants
to continue with deployment even after
deprecation.

The logic is to check for neutron-opendaylight.yaml
environment file passed to overcloud deploy command.
If yes, ask for user confirmation before starting
deployment.

Change-Id: I1b16aab11591fac610cd4bf49a0927f1ec947146
Closes-Bug: #1827366

subject: WIP - Add the mandatory flag
messages:
[{'account_id': 29364, 'date': '2019-05-14 14:31:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2019-05-17 14:12:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2019-05-17 14:20:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Hi Gabriele,

Thanks for the patch - this will be a useful feature.

However I gave you some bad advice when I suggested we make this feature configurable per call.  We can't do that since all call arguments are application defined (and transparent to oslo.messaging).  Adding the option parameter will break stuff badly.

Again, my bad - sorry.

So if we take a step back this feature will have to be implemented as a new parameter to the __init__ of the RPCClient class.

That should make the implementation easier - you won't have to monkey around with the message envelope and all that.

Take a look at the way we pass 'call_monitor_timeout' as an example - you'll do the same to get the flag down into the amqpdriver.py/impl_rabbit.py code.

Most of the other stuff looks good so far.  One thing you'll need to do is avoid adding all that whitespace - it's unnecessary and makes the patch hard to read (perhaps your editor is adding that?)."}, {'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2019-05-17 14:25:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 29364, 'date': '2019-05-21 12:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

closed in favor of https://review.opendev.org/#/c/660373/'}]

commit_message:
WIP - Add the mandatory flag

Add mandatory flag to handle the no-routed messages.
In this way it is possible to know if a message reaches a queue or not.
It raises an exception in case a message is not routed.

Note:
- This is a WIP
- This is just a an idea, I wanted to add a generic parameter called
"option", so we can add more options during the publish.
See the gist[1] for details.

Closes-bug: #1661510

1- https://gist.github.com/Gsantomaggio/bff62fe28210622cfa9d32d164412800

Change-Id: Ic8f87208a0891dd21e99530ad0cf5caf22d2e785

commit_message:
Do not set port addresses on LSP while port not bound

FIP that points to VIP port could not have addresses
specified [1]. Router pipeline will try to resolve
ARP requests internally from LSP instead looking for
actual MAC address from LSP where VIP exists at this moment.

Lets not set this address till the port is bound.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1707241

Change-Id: I36261701be393584ad4b00ced96273736339b03c
Closes-Bug: #1789686

commit_message:
Fix clone list for opendev changes

Disable CentOS gating to allow the galera_server percona-release fix
to merge[1].

openSUSE 42.3 gating is removed since it uses LXC containers and our
LXC build process is broken on 42.3, plus 42.3 is scheduled for EOL
soon.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/660141/

Depends-On: I09182143f4cf9adf186973dff513116da42e3f91
Change-Id: I67ebe9e813c95a3a8bcf204678ddccbcea7a45cd
(cherry picked from commit 7a3e52892990f84df5f4d53f069a8d3511bd14a8)
(cherry picked from commit 458b26d4bdadf390e36a9be2b3f861fbb627ca18)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-05 18:02:25.000000000', 'message': 'Build and use tagged images in CI

With the creation of the openstack-helm-images repo, we should
define how we'll build and consume images.

We should have jobs that are "stable" for deployers, running
in periodics, using 'fixed' images produced by
openstack-helm-images.

We should also have by default "bleeding edge" images, which
are built directly from openstack-helm-images repo and
consumed locally.

This describes the process of getting there.

Change-Id: I183d4838cdbe8857284d391f0ebb044a355be4dd
'}, {'created': '2018-11-06 14:53:49.000000000', 'message': 'Build and use tagged images in CI

commit_message:
Build and use tagged images in CI

With the creation of the openstack-helm-images repo, we should
define how we'll build and consume images.

We should have jobs that are "stable" for deployers, running
in periodics, using 'fixed' images produced by
openstack-helm-images.

We should also have by default "bleeding edge" images, which
are built directly from openstack-helm-images repo and
consumed locally.

This describes the process of getting there.

Change-Id: I183d4838cdbe8857284d391f0ebb044a355be4dd

commit_message:
Revert "remove old common_functions script"

This reverts commit ab5b7a16c850fe0168e99af271a4adffd479c1e7.

The script is still used within tripleo.sh, when called with --delorean-build.

Change-Id: I512b4eac3ce1536e726b248801d1c5ddc3a7500c

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-01 22:43:46.000000000', 'message': 'Fix guestfs.set_backend_settings call

This method takes a list of strings. It was never failing
because python-libguestfs takes the input and casts it to
a list, which turns "force_tcg" into:

  ['f', 'o', 'r', 'c', 'e', '_', 't', 'c', 'g']

Which is obviously not correct.

http://libguestfs.org/guestfs.3.html#guestfs_set_backend_settings

This fixes that issue and leaves a TODO about investigating
the usage of set_backend_setting for just setting the
single force_tcg value instead of overrwriting all backend
settings.

Credit to Clark Boylan for identifying the issue.

Change-Id: I36edfaf30fd0cc234f929fd6937d07b6a1b646ae
Partial-Bug: #1735823
